PM11:13am

UBS

PM11:14am

Bulk of group performing well, helped by cost savings
Vittorio Colao has announced he is stepping down after 10 years as CEO and will be succeeded by CFO Nick Read. Q4 results were ahead with Q4 organic service revenue growth of +1.4% (cons +1.1%). Top-line trends were in-line to ahead for the bulk of the group, although Spain was light (see body of note for more detail). FY EBITDA grew +11.8% organically to €14,737m (a 0.7% beat vs cons at €14,629m) – the EBITDA beat was driven by a €90m one-off benefit in Germany due a legal settlement over carriage fees. Excluding one-offs (roaming drag/handset financing/settlements), underlying EBITDA grew a solid +7.9% as VOD benefits from a growing top-line and a tailwind from cost savings. EFCF grew +34% to €5,417m (vs cons €5,219m).

A. M. Morning all.
Mouselet Good morning assorted people. What is a good remedy to thinking that everything is going to Hell in a badly-designed handbasket?
PM11:14am

Guidance marginally light on EBITDA – softness in Spain/Italy
VOD has guided for FY-19 EBITDA to grow 1-5% underlying (after adjusting for one-offs in FY-18) to give EBITDA of €14.15-14.65bn. The mid-point of EBITDA guidance at €14.40bn is marginally light vs cons of €14.514bn and the delta relates to timing issues around the removal of 28 day billing in Italy (this was unwound in April but offsetting price rises will only come in end of May) and also some softness in Spain. EFCF guidance of greater than €5.2bn (cons €5.217bn) is in-line.

11:14 am
PM11:15am

Muted service revenue growth for Q1/Q2
Expectations for Italy are low given the expected entry of Iliad into the Italian mobile market, but with Spain also likely to see negative organic service revenue growth, consensus is likely to factor in close to 0% service revenue growth for Q1/Q2 on an IAS18 basis. However, on an IFRS15 basis that adjusting for handset financing drag, underlying service revenue growth would be closer to +1% for Q1/Q2 (see body of note for more detail).
Valuation: PT based on SOTP/DCF
We see VOD as cheap on 8.2% EFCF yield on a calendarised basis for 2018E (pre-spectrum) and offering a 6.5% dividend yield. We re-iterate our view that the bulk of the group is performing well and will benefit from cost savings. However, we think the main drivers for the share price will be visibility over Iliad’s entry into the Italian mobile market (summer 2018) and visibility regulatory clearance for the LBTY deal (mid 2019).

PM11:27am

Key questions going forward for the US market
In our January report we highlighted a number of key unknowns for the US sports
betting market, in particular for the European operators. We think the key areas to
consider are: 1) potential tax rates, 2) whether sports betting will be regulated for
online as well as land-based, 3) whether operators will need a physical presence in the
US (or in each specific state) in order to obtain a license, 4) potentially high levels of
competition from other operators such as US casinos and state lottery operators,
increasing marketing costs, 5) whether sports leagues will demand an 'integrity fee'.
We believe that a higher than expected tax rate and/or integrity fee could lead to
unattractive odds/prices for consumers, potentially discouraging consumers from
moving to regulated operators, allowing the unregulated market to prevail (a view
shared by the American Gaming Association/Oxford Economics).

PM11:37am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: 1H18 revenues were up 19.5% to £2,183m (UBSe £2,126m vs H1 2017: £1,827m) with RPS (CC) of 8.3% broadly aligned with UBSe c9%. 2018 PBT came in at -£68m (UBSe -£113m, cons -£55m, 1H17: -c£212m).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Ancillary revenues were up 15.1% (or 1.8% per passenger). Constant currency ex-fuel unit costs were down (1.6%) in H1 but full year guidance was revised upwards to +2% (vs. prior guidance +1%).
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Guidance changed upwards and expects headline PBT of £530-580m (previous £475m pre ramp up costs or £375m reported) also helped by £25m favourable FX movement. This compares with UBSe £455m reported, cons reported £405m. The company expects yields in the second half to be slightly positive and FY capacity c+5%.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect a good reaction considering guidance upgrade.

A strong revenue per seat improvement (+9.5% constant currency, excluding the Berlin Tegel start-up operations) was at the upper end of management’s guidance (up mid/high-single digits). There was some help from the timing of Easter (partially in March and thus H1 this year), but market capacity growth was moderate in the wake of numerous airline failures last year with surviving airlines not fully filling the gap.

DM11:54am

Premier Foods (Premier) has reported preliminary results for the 52 weeks ended 31st March ahead of subdued expectations, with a strong Q4 performance benefiting from colder weather, the timing of Easter and pipeline fill in Australia, augmenting improving delivery on its strategic growth priorities.

DM11:55am

Total sales increased 3.6% in the year (the upper end of the Group’s 2-4% target range), with Q4 sales ahead by 7% with the drivers for the outperformance outlined above. Non-branded sales remain the driver for revenue growth, up by

15% through Q4, though we are encouraged by >5% growth in Branded sales over the same period. Trading Profit of £123m is reported (SC forecast £116.2m), yoy growth of 5.1%. CPTP was £78.6m, so again a beat to expectations (SC forecast £74.2m), growth of 5.9%. The Group has delivered EPS of 7.6p, (SC forecast 7.2p) so growth yoy of 6.4%.

IWG is back in play. Approaches from multiple parties suggest that this time IWG is going private, ending 17 years of chequered experience on the stock-market. Much depends on the attitudes of founder Mark Dixon and the Board, but with a competitive auction in sight, we see a 320p-350p exit price as achievable.
